ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about Hebrew culture while refining my skills in creative writing (dramatic writing, newspaper writing, short story writing, poem/song writing).
I gained the skill of being better able to read and write in Hebrew, and I gained insight into Israeli history and culture surrounding creative writing.
I learned how to write and edit a creative writing assignment in Hebrew from start to finish. I also learned to read and analyze different types of writing in Hebrew.
I learned to read high-level texts in Hebrew and understand the nuances of each text.
I learned a lot about Israeli/Judaic short stories, drama, poetry and journalism, while also improving my active writing and speaking skills.
I learned a lot about influential and/or typifying pieces of literature in Hebrew and Israeli culture. I expanded my vocabulary. I exercised my creative muscles in the unit projects.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A major strength is our professor. She cares about her students and the content of the course, making it very enjoyable.

A strength of this course is the engagement. I enjoyed being able to converse with my peers in the class. 

A weakness of this course is the how the homework was given. I felt that homework did not reflect what we did in class. They were mostly grammar based, despite that never being spoken about in class.

Strengths: exposes students to a variety of texts and styles
Weaknesses: classes are often repetitive
I would like there to be more writing guidance.

strengths: engaging discussions with classmates, varied assignments to improve both active and passive knowledge of modern Hebrew, lots of cultural insights
weaknesses: none really, I highly enjoyed this course, maybe it would have been even better to read a longer work in Hebrew rather than merely very short texts

This course is extremely well organized and the students know what to expect from the consistent workload and style of assignments. Engagement with technology is well done. There is breadth and depth to each topic covered. Unit assignments are fun and fitting. I would have appreciated covering more grammar in an organized way.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student because it allows us to improve our Hebrew writing and comprehension without the stress accompanied by other courses at Yale.
I would recommend this course to another student if they had a genuine interest in Hebrew Writing. If not, it is an unnecessarily difficult way to fulfill a language requirement.
Yes. It is a good Hebrew credit and I feel it significantly improved my reading and writing
Yes, it was very interesting and I read a lot.

Yes, if you are fluent (L5) in Hebrew, I would definitely recommend this course. Even if you do not have experience with creative writing, you should not be intimidated-- through the readings and class discussions you will feel inspired.
I would recommend it to someone who wants to keep up with their Hebrew and expand their cultural references.
